awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of ASIC's Suite for Analog Processing of Signals from Large Arrays of Silicon-Strip Detectors and PSD-Capable Scintillators
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the ASIC (Application Specific Integrated Circuit) chip fabrication that will expand the capabilities of two low energy nuclear physics experiments aimed at understanding the complex structure of exotic nuclei.  The first experiment will take place at the NSCL (National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory) and will compare oxygen and lithium isotopes, which have mirror-like structure and can lead to the nucleosynthesis of heavier isotopes such as argon and chlorine.  The second experiment will take place at Florida State University and investigate reactions that play a major role in understanding the products of explosive astrophysical events such as novae and x-ray bursts.  The undergraduate and graduate students involved in the project will receive excellent preparation for professional careers in forefront physics and engineering and in the growing overlap areas.

More specifically, this award supports the development, design and fabrication of ASIC chips that extend the scientific reach of (at least) two programs.  One of these programs, led by the Washington University reactions group, uses the invariant mass technique to study the continuum structure of proton-rich nuclei. This program will use the upgraded HINP (Heavy Ion Nuclear Physics) chip at NSCL to search for the ground state in O-11, which is the mirror of Li-11, the prototype exotic nucleus (huge n/p asymmetry). These measurements, and others planned by this and other groups, require electronics with both large dynamic range and excellent resolution, features included in the new ASIC design.  A second empowered experimental program will use (d,n) reactions as a surrogate for astrophysically relevant (p,gamma) reactions. Such experiments have to contend with physical neutron cross talk (in the neutron detectors themselves) and gamma background. The technology of the PSD (Pulse Shape Discrimination) chip enables large arrays of neutron-sensitive detectors that can reduce these problems. These experiments will be led by a Florida State University group, initially at their local facility and later at both Argonne National Laboratory and the future Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB).

por.por_cntn:
Researchers that conduct nuclear physics experiments where it is necessary to detect and monitor radiation require instruments in order to perform their experiments.  Modern experiments generally involve a very large number of radiation detectors (i.e. perhaps hundred of "channels").  There are two general class of experiments. Many experiments only require high resolution energy measurements while others require both knowledge of particle energy and radiation particle type.  Experiments requiring high-resolution energy measurements alone frequently employ what is known as "silicon strip detectors" while experiments which demand knowledge of both energy and particle type typically use detectors known as "scintillators".  As a result of the large number of channels which are typically encountered, the use of discrete electronics to create instruments for use in these physics experiments has become impractical and much too costly. 

This NSF-MRI addressed this problem by creating a family of multi-channel integrated circuits (ICs) for use in nuclear physics experiments where radiation must be deteced and monitored. The circuits which were developed as a result of this NSF-MRI are better performing versions, with additional features than what was offered by earlier integrated circuits developed by our group.  The group is a collaboration of Electrical Engineers from Southern Illinois University Edwardsville (SIUE) and researchers from the Nuclear Reactions Laboratory at Washington University in St. Louis.  Three complex ICs, each containing thousands of transistors and occupying just a few square millimeters of area, were designed, simulated, physically layed out, fabricated, and finally tested.

The first chip was an eight channel IC for use in experiments where scintillators are used.  The technique which was implemented to determine particle type is known as Pulse Shape discrimination (PSD) and hence the IC is called PSD8C in which the 8C denotes channel count. (See PSD8C plot.)  The IC has recently been incorporated into a large detector array at Texas A&M University.  The Texas Neutron detector array, or TexNeut array, consists of multiple scintillators coupled to form what are called pseudobars that can be arranged to suit the needs of various rnuclear reactions. The PSD8C IC performance is excellent.

The second IC developed is capable of providing timing information to the PSD8C IC and is called CFD16C.  (See CFD16C plot).  This timing information is critical and the IC can replace a rather large printed circuit board containing discrete electronics that is currently being used. The CFD refers to the IC's use of what are called Constant Fraction Discriminators (CFD) to provide high quality timing information. This IC also served as a valuable test circuit since the same CFD circuits are required by the third IC, described below.

The third IC developed was christened HINP16C (Heavy Ion Nuclear Physics - 16 Channels) and is intended for use with silicon strip detectors.  (See HINP16C plot).  This is the most complex and largest of the three ICs.  The IC is approximately 5 mm by 7 mm with an electronic component count approaching 100,000 devices.  While fully functional, a modified version of  HINP16C is headed in for fabrication, perhaps as early as Fall 2022, to address performance issues which were identified during testing. Funds from sources other than this NSF-MRI will be used to cover the cost of fabrication of the modified HINP16C IC.

In addition to this NSF-MRI producing small, cost-effective, high-performing instrumentation for the low- and intermediate-energy nuclear physics community, it also helped train a large number of electrical engineering graduate students to take jobs in the area of integrated circuit design. More than a dozen graduate students worked on the integrated circuits whose development was funded by this NSF-MRI.  Approximately one-half of these students are now working as integrated circuit engineers for companies such as Apple, Intel, and Qualcomm or pursuing doctoral degrees in the area of integrated circuit design. This success story was in large part due to their involvement in this NSF-MRI and the knowledge they gained from working on the ICs described herein.
